sen.j: 田辺藩（たなべはん）は江戸時代、丹後国にあった藩の1つ。
sen.e: Tanabe han is one of hans in the Province of Tango in the Edo period.
Tanabe han was one of the hans in the Province of Tango during the Edo period.
Tanabe domain was one of the domains in Tango Province during the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 「○○藩」「○○国」の表現を修正しました。

sen.j: 別名、舞鶴藩（まいづるはん）と呼称される事も多い。
sen.e: It is often called another name Maizuru han.
They were often called by another name, Maizuru han.
They were often called by another name, Maizuru domain.

sen.j: 藩庁は田辺城 (丹後国)（京都府舞鶴市）。
sen.e: The office of the han was Tanabe Castle (the Province of Tango), (Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture).
The office of the han was Tanabe Castle (the Province of Tango), (Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture).
The office of the domain was Tanabe-jo Castle (Tango Province), (Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture).
sen.cmt: 「○○藩」、「○○城」、「○○国」の表現を修正しました。

sen.j: 丹後国は元々一色氏が守護を務める国であったが、天正7年（1579年）、細川幽斎は明智光秀とともに反信長連合の一角だった一色氏らを滅ぼし丹後国・丹波国を制圧し功績を挙げた。
sen.e: The province of Tango was originally a province where Isshiki clan controlled as Shugo; military governor, but in 1579 Yusai HOSOKAWA together with Mitsuhide AKECHI defeated a member group of the anti-Nobunaga alliance including Isshiki clan to accomplish an achievement to conquer the Province of Tango and Province of Tamba.
sen.cmt: 丹波国→th State of Tamba→the Province of Tamba
sen.e: The province of Tango was originally a province where the Isshiki clan controlled as Shugo; military governor, but in 1579 Yusai HOSOKAWA together with Mitsuhide AKECHI defeated a member group of the anti-Nobunaga alliance including the Isshiki clan to conquer the Provinces of Tango and Tamba.

Tango Province was originally a province where the Isshiki clan controlled as Shugo; military governor, but in 1579 Yusai HOSOKAWA together with Mitsuhide AKECHI defeated a member group of the anti-Nobunaga alliance including the Isshiki clan to conquer Tango and Tanba Provinces.
sen.cmt: 「○○国」の表記を修正、またTamba→Tanbaとしました。

sen.j: 藤孝は恩賞とし丹後一国を与えられ田辺城 (丹後国)を築き、舞鶴を拠点に丹後一国を治めた。
sen.e: Fujitaka was given a province of Tango as a reward, built Tanabe Castle (the Province of Tango), and was headquartered in Maizuru and governed the province of Tango.
Fujitaka was given the province of Tango as a reward, built Tanabe Castle (the Province of Tango), and was headquartered in Maizuru and governed the province of Tango.
Fujitaka was given the province of Tango as a reward, built Tanabe-jo Castle (Tango Province), and was headquartered in Maizuru and governed the province of Tango.
sen.cmt: 田辺城、丹波国の表記を一部修正しました。

sen.j: その後、天正10年(1582年)6月2日に親戚関係にあった明智光秀が本能寺の変を起こし、藤孝自身も加担するよう誘われるが、反光秀の立場を貫き、豊臣秀吉から丹後の本領を安堵されている。
sen.e: Thereafter, on June 2, 1582 Mitsuhide AKECHI, who was his relative, staged Honnoji Temple Incident, and Fujitaka himself was also asked to be involeved in the incident but he sticked to his position of anti-Mitsuhide and was approved of the main domain of Tango by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

Thereafter, on June 2, 1582 Mitsuhide AKECHI, who was his relative, staged the Honnoji Temple Incident, and Fujitaka himself was also asked to become involved in the incident, but he stuck to his position being anti-Mitsuhide and was approved as the main domain of Tango by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

Thereafter, on June 2, 1582 Mitsuhide AKECHI, who was his relative, staged the Honnoji Temple Incident, and Fujitaka himself was also asked to become involved in the incident, but he stuck to his position being anti-Mitsuhide and was approved as the main domain of Tango by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: しかし藤孝は、親戚であった光秀の裏切りの責任をとる形で嫡男の細川忠興に家督を譲って隠居した。
sen.e: However, Fujitaka transferred the head of the family to the heir Tadaoki HOSOKAWA to retire as he took responsibility of his relative Mitsuhide's betrayal.
However, Fujitaka transferred the head of the family to the heir Tadaoki HOSOKAWA in order to retire because he took responsibility for his relative Mitsuhide's betrayal.
However, Fujitaka transferred the head of the family to the heir Tadaoki HOSOKAWA in order to retire because he took responsibility for his relative Mitsuhide's betrayal.

sen.j: その際、隠居城として宮津城を築き、舞鶴市から移った。
sen.e: At that time he built Miyazu Castle as a castle to retire and moved from Maizuru City.
At that time he built Miyazu Castle as a castle to retire in and moved from Maizuru City.
At that time he built Miyazu-jo Castle as a castle to retire in and moved from Maizuru City.

sen.j: しかし、関ヶ原の戦い時には、ふたたび、舞鶴城に戻り、留守中の息子の代理を務めた。
sen.e: However, he came back to Maizuru Castle in the Battle of Sekigahara and worked on behalf of his son who was away for the battle.
However, he returned to Maizuru Castle during the Battle of Sekigahara and worked on behalf of his son who was participating in the battle.
However, he returned to Maizuru-jo Castle during the Battle of Sekigahara and worked on behalf of his son who was participating in the battle.
sen.cmt: ○○城の表記を修正、およびスペースを半角に変更しました。

sen.j: 慶長5年（1600年）、関ヶ原の戦い後、細川氏は豊前国中津藩へ転封された。
sen.e: In 1600, Hosokawa clan was transferred to Nakatsu domain of the Province of Buzen after the Battle of Sekigahara.
sen.cmt: 豊前国→the Province of Nakatsu→the Province of Buzen
sen.e: In 1600, the Hosokawa clan was transferred to the Nakatsu domain in the Province of Buzen after the Battle of Sekigahara.
In 1600, the Hosokawa clan was transferred to the Nakatsu domain in Buzen Province after the Battle of Sekigahara.

sen.j: かわって信濃国飯田市より、京極高知が田辺城に入城した。
sen.e: Then Takatomo KYOGOKU moved into Tanabe Castle from Iida City, the Province of Shinano.
Then Takatomo KYOGOKU moved into Tanabe Castle from Iida City, the Province of Shinano.
Then Takatomo KYOGOKU moved into Tanabe-jo Castle from Iida City, Shinano Province.
sen.cmt: ○○城および○○国の表記を修正しました。

tit.e: The original forefather of the domain: Takamitsu KYOGOKU
The original forefather of the domain: Takamitsu KYOGOKU
The original forefather of the domain: Takamitsu KYOGOKU

sen.j: 京極高知は嫡男の京極高広を宮津藩に、京極高三を舞鶴藩（田辺藩）に、京極高通を峰山藩に入れ、丹後を3藩に分割統治させた。
sen.e: Takatomo KYOGOKU ordered his heir Takahiro KYOGOKU to move into the Miyazu domain, Takamitsu KYOGOKU to move into the Maizuru domain (the Tanabe domain), and Takamichi KYOGOKU to move into Mineyama domain, whereby Tango was divided into three domains to govern.

Takatomo KYOGOKU ordered his heir Takahiro KYOGOKU to move to the Miyazu domain, Takamitsu KYOGOKU to move to the Maizuru domain (the Tanabe domain), and Takamichi KYOGOKU to move to the Mineyama domain, and Tango was divided into three domains to govern.

Takatomo KYOGOKU ordered his heir Takahiro KYOGOKU to move to the Miyazu domain, Takamitsu KYOGOKU to move to the Maizuru domain (the Tanabe domain), and Takamichi KYOGOKU to move to the Mineyama domain, and Tango Province was divided into three domains to govern.

sen.j: 京極高三により、ここに初めて舞鶴藩（田辺藩）が成立した。
sen.e: By Takamitsu KYOGOKU the Maizuru domain (the Tanabe domain) was first established.
the Maizuru domain (the Tanabe domain) was first established by Takamitsu KYOGOKU.
The Maizuru domain (the Tanabe domain) was first established by Takamitsu KYOGOKU.
sen.cmt: 文頭の"the"を大文字に変更しました。

sen.j: 京極家は近江源氏佐々木氏の末裔であり、有名な京極道誉（佐々木道誉）の子孫である。
sen.e: The House of Kyogoku is a descendant of Omi Genji Sasaki clan and also a descendant of famous Doyo KYOGOKU (Doyo SASAKI).
The House of Kyogoku was descended from Omi Genji Sasaki clan and was also a descendant of the famous Doyo KYOGOKU (Doyo SASAKI).
The Kyogoku family was descended from Omi Genji Sasaki clan and was also a descendant of the famous Doyo KYOGOKU (Doyo SASAKI).
sen.cmt: 「京極家」の表現を修正しました。

sen.j: 寛永13年、京極高直が二代藩主となった。
sen.e: In 1673 Takanao KYOGOKU became the second generation lord of the Maizuru domain.
sen.cmt: 京極高直→Takanao KYOGOKU, Wikipedia でしか調べることができませんでした
sen.e: In 1673 Takanao KYOGOKU became the second generation lord of the Maizuru domain.
In 1673 Takanao KYOGOKU became the second generation lord of the Maizuru domain.

sen.j: 三代京極高盛は寛文3年（1663年）に弟の京極高門に2千石を分知し、また寛文8年（1668年）には、但馬国豊岡藩に転封となった。
sen.e: The third generation lord Takamori KYOGOKU subdivided the domain of 2,000 koku to his younger brother Takakado KYOGOKU, and in 1668 was transferred to the Toyooka domain of the Province of Tajima.

The third generation lord Takamori KYOGOKU subdivided and gave a domain of 2,000 koku to his younger brother Takakado KYOGOKU, and in 1668 he was transferred to the Toyooka domain in the Province of Tajima.
The third generation lord Takamori KYOGOKU subdivided and gave a domain of 2,000 koku to his younger brother Takakado KYOGOKU, and in 1668 he was transferred to the Toyooka domain in Tajima Province.

sen.j: 代わって同年に、牧野親成・牧野富成兄弟が摂津国より、3万5000石で入城。
sen.e: In the same year, Chikashige MAKINO and Tomishige MAKINo brothers moved into the castle with 35,000 koku from the Province of Settsu.
In the same year, brothers Chikashige MAKINO and Tomishige MAKINO moved into the castle with 35,000 koku from the Province of Settsu.
In the same year, brothers Chikashige MAKINO and Tomishige MAKINO moved into the castle with 35,000 koku from Settsu Province.

sen.j: 以後牧野家によって明治維新を迎え、舞鶴県に至った。
sen.e: Thereafter the House of Makino had governed the domain till the Meiji Restoration, and after that it became Maizuru Prefecture.
Thereafter the House of Makino had governed the domain till the Meiji Restoration, and after that it became Maizuru Prefecture.
Thereafter the Makino family had governed the domain till the Meiji Restoration, and after that it became Maizuru Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 「牧野家」の表現を修正しました。

sen.j: 田辺牧野家について
sen.e: The House of Tanabe-Makino
The House of Tanabe-Makino
The Tanabe-Makino family

sen.j: 藩祖は牧野康成 (戦国武将)（やすしげ）。
sen.e: The original forefather of the domain is Yasushige MAKINO (sengoku samurai).
The original forefather of the domain is Yasushige MAKINO (sengoku samurai).
The original forefather of the domain is Yasushige MAKINO (busho (Japanese military commander) in the Sengoku Period).
sen.cmt: 「戦国武将」の表記を修正しました。

sen.j: 康成は初名を正勝、通称を半右衛門という。
sen.e: Yasushige was first named "Masakatsu," aka. Han'emon.
Yasushige was first named "Masakatsu," aka. Han'emon.
Yasushige was first named "Masakatsu," aka. Hanemon.
sen.cmt: "Han'emon"のアポストロフィーをはずしました。

sen.j: その父は牛久保牧野氏寄騎の牧野定成（八大夫）とされる。
sen.e: His father is considered to be Sadanari Makino, a yoriki, assistant of a family, of Ushikubo MAKINO (Hachidayu).
His father is considered to be Sadanari Makino, a yoriki, assistant of the family of Ushikubo MAKINO (Hachidayu).
His father is considered to be Sadanari MAKINO (Hachidayu), a yoriki, assistant of the Ushikubo Makino clan.
sen.cmt: (八大夫)の位置、および「牛久保牧野氏」の表現を修正しました。

sen.j: 三河国在住時代は宝飯郡平井（現・愛知県宝飯郡小坂井町平井）に知行地があった。
sen.e: During the period when he was living in the Province of Mikawa the fiefs were in Hirai of Hoi County (the present Hirai, Kosakai Cho, Hoi County, Aichi Prefecture).
During the period when he was living in the Province of Mikawa the fiefs were in Hirai of Hoi County (the present Hirai, Kosakai Cho, Hoi County, Aichi Prefecture).
During the period when he was living in Mikawa Province the fiefs were in Hirai of Hoi County (the present Hirai, Kosakai Cho, Hoi County, Aichi Prefecture).

sen.j: 永禄8年（1564年）徳川氏に所属し翌年8月平井（92貫文の地）を安堵されている。
sen.e: It belong to Tokugawa clan in 1564 and in August next year Hirai (land of 92 kanmon) was approved.
It belong to the Tokugawa clan in 1564 and in August the next year, Hirai (land of 92 kanmon) was approved.
It belonged to the Tokugawa clan in 1564 and in August the next year, Hirai (land of 92 kanmon) was approved.

sen.j: なお、定成（この実名にも諸説有り）以前の牧野山城守の系譜は確定したものが知られていない。
sen.e: Incidentally, the family tree of Makino Yamashiro no Kami before Sadanari (as for this name there are also a few theories) is not known as being established.
Incidentally, the family tree of Makino Yamashiro no Kami before Sadanari (as for this name there are also a few theories) is not known as whether it was being established or not
Incidentally, the family tree of Makino Yamashiro no Kami before Sadanari (as for this name there are also a few theories) is not known as whether it was being established or not

sen.j: 牛久保城主一門にしてはなぜ寄騎の扱いであったか不明な点も多い。
sen.e: There are many unclear points as to why the Makino clan was ranked as a yoriki considering the clan being the family of the lord of Ushikubo Castle.
There are many unclear points as to why the Makino clan was ranked as a yoriki considering the clan being the family of the lord of Ushikubo Castle.
There are many unclear points as to why the Makino clan was ranked as a yoriki considering the clan being the family of the lord of Ushikubo-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 牛久保城の表記を修正しました。

sen.j: 安土桃山時代以前の牧野氏のルーツは、不明な点や矛盾が多く、複数の異なった系譜が伝わり、また徳川氏帰属後は反徳川の急先鋒だった三河牛窪城主・牧野保成との関係を意図的に遠ざけたとも考えられ、これも系譜関係の不明確さの一因となっている。
sen.e: The family tree is unclear because as for the roots of the Makino clan before the Azuchi Momoyama era, many unclear points and discrepancies exsist, and there are some different family trees are prevailing, and because as for those after the Makino clan belonged to the Tokugawa clan, it is considered that the Makino clan intentionally kept away from Lord of Mikawa Ushikubo Castle Yasushige MAKINO who was one of the anti-Tokugawa radicals.

The family tree is unclear because as for the roots of the Makino clan before the Azuchi Momoyama era, many unclear points and discrepancies exsist, and there are some different family trees prevailing, and because of those after the Makino clan belonged to the Tokugawa clan, it is considered that the Makino clan intentionally kept away from Lord of Mikawa Ushikubo Castle Yasushige MAKINO who was one of the anti-Tokugawa radicals.

The family tree is unclear because as for the roots of the Makino clan before the Azuchi Momoyama period, many unclear points and discrepancies exsist, and there are some different family trees prevailing, and because of those after the Makino clan belonged to the Tokugawa clan, it is considered that the Makino clan intentionally kept away from Lord of Mikawa Ushikubo-jo Castle Yasushige MAKINO who was one of the anti-Tokugawa radicals.
sen.cmt: 「○○時代」、および「○○城」の表現を修正しました。

sen.j: 田辺藩主牧野氏と長岡藩主牧野氏との系譜関係を完全・確実に伝える史料は知られていない。
sen.e: There is no family tree known that shows completely and certainly the family tree relationship between the lord of the Tanabe domain the Makino clan and the lord of the Nagaoka domain the Makino clan.

There is no family tree known that shows completely and with certainly, the family tree relationship between the lord of the Tanabe domain, the Makino clan, and the lord of the Nagaoka domain, the Makino clan.

There is no family tree known that shows completely and with certainly, the family tree relationship between the lord of the Tanabe domain, the Makino clan, and the lord of the Nagaoka domain, the Makino clan.

sen.j: 天正18年（1590年）に康成は武蔵国足立郡石戸に5千石を与えられ、康成の3男の牧野信成 (関宿藩主)は慶長4年（1599年）父の遺跡を継ぎ、慶長11年（1606年）より大番頭、小姓組番頭、書院番頭などを歴任。
sen.e: In 1590 Yasushige was given 5,000 koku in Ishito, Adachi County, the Province of Musashi, in 1599 Yashushige's third son Nobushige MAKINO (Lord of Sekishuku) inherited his father, and since 1606 Nobushige had worked as Grand Head, Head of page office, Head of military patrol and so on.

In 1590 Yasushige was given 5,000 koku in Ishito, Adachi County, in the Province of Musashi, in 1599 Yashushige's third son Nobushige MAKINO (Lord of Sekishuku) inherited his father's property, and since 1606 Nobushige had worked as Grand Head, Head of page office, Head of a military patrol, etc.

In 1590 Yasushige was given 5,000 koku in Ishito, Adachi County, in Musashi Province, in 1599 Yashushige's third son Nobushige MAKINO (Lord of the Sekiyado domain) inherited his father's property, and since 1606 Nobushige had worked as Grand Head, Head of page office, Head of a military patrol, etc.
sen.cmt: 「○○城」の表現を修正、関宿藩主（せきやどはんしゅ）の読み、表現を修正しました。

sen.j: 寛永10年（1633年）の加増で大名に列し、武蔵国石戸藩1万1千石として立藩。
sen.e: The clan was ranked as Daimyo because of the koku increase in 1633 and Ishido domain, the Province of Musashi was established as 11,000 koku.
The clan was ranked as a Daimyo because the koku increase in 1633 and Ishido domain, in the Province of Musashi, was established with 11,000 koku.
The clan was ranked as a Daimyo because the koku increase in 1633 and Ishido domain, in Musashi Province, was established with 11,000 koku.

sen.j: 正保元年（1644年）の加増で関宿城主となり下総国関宿藩入封となる。
sen.e: The clan became the lord of Lord of Sekishuku because of the koku increase in 1644 and moved into Sekishuku domain, Shimofusa Province.
The clan became the lord of Sekishuku because the koku increase in 1644, and they moved into the Sekishuku domain in Shimofusa Province.
The clan became the lord of Sekiyado-jo Castle because the koku increase in 1644, and they moved into the Sekiyado domain in Shimofusa Province.
sen.cmt: 関宿(せきやど)城主の読みと表現を修正しました。

sen.j: 信成の子牧野親成が段々に加増され、寛文8年（1660年）に封地を移されて丹後田辺藩3万5千万石の藩主になった。
sen.e: The koku was gradually increased in the generation of son of Nobushige, Chikashige MAKINO, and in 1660 he was transferred to become a lord of Tango Tanabe domain with 35,000 koku.
sen.cmt: ３万５千万石とありますが、３万五千石でないでしょうか。ご確認ください。→www.geocities.co.jp/nkks437758/tango_tanabe.html
sen.e: The koku was gradually increased during the generation of the son of Nobushige, Chikashige MAKINO, and in 1660 he was transferred to become the lord of the Tango Tanabe domain with 35,000 koku.
The koku was gradually increased during the generation of the son of Nobushige, Chikashige MAKINO, and in 1660 he was transferred to become the lord of the Tango Tanabe domain with 35,000 koku.

sen.j: 以後、幕末まで歴代が同藩で封を重ね、明治維新後に旧藩主家は子爵となり華族に列した。
sen.e: Thereafter, the clan continued to be the lords in this domain untill the end of the Edo period, and after the Meiji Restoration the former houses of lords became viscounts and were raised on to the peerage.

Thereafter, the clan continued to be the lord in this domain untill the end of the Edo period, and after the Meiji Restoration the former houses of the lords became viscounts and were on the same level as their peers.

Thereafter, the clan continued to be the lord in this domain untill the end of the Edo period, and after the Meiji Restoration the former houses of the lords became viscounts and were on the same level as their peers.
